rows.value: I Have ... I WIsh I Had ...

rows.name: help_text
rows.value:
The two routines
* "I have ☐, and I wish I had ☐"
* "I have ☐, and I only need ☐" 

are a way to attach engaging stories to the questions of how many more do I need and how many do I need to take away. For young children, the repetition makes it a familiar scenario they can jump right into.

This is a task that lends itself to being used for addition and subtraction of many types of numbers in early mathematics - small whole numbers, larger whole numbers, integers, fractions, mixed numbers, and decimals.

rows.name: topics_text
rows.value:
While all these problems can be solved using Counting On or subtraction, a number of different perspectives can encourage different methods to be employed.

If you point to a number path or number line and say that you have 4 and you need 6, then your students will look at the relationship of those two numbers and either see that they are 2 apart or that they can Count On from 4 to 6 by adding 2. This also encourages them to see that the difference of 4 and 6 is 2.

On the other hand, if you say you have 4 and you need 6, and you follow that up with the question of what do you need to add to 4 to get 6, then your students will see that this can be thought of as an unknown addition problem with one unknown – 4 + ☐ = 6.

Similarly, "I have ☐, and I only need ☐" can be presented as a difference problem, an addition problem, or a subtraction problem.

rows.name: advice_text
rows.value:
While this task pretty much presents itself, you can embellish it to make the discussion livelier. Children are always more engaged when a calculation is wrapped in an interesting story.

**Examples:**
* You have 3 players for a team and you need 5 players in all. 
* You have 1 pieces of candy and you wish you had 3 pieces of candy.

rows.name: intro_2_text
rows.value: The tasks are separated by the types of numbers and by whether "you wish you had ☐" or "you only need ☐."
